trial_identification.studytitle: The effect of spinal manipulation on lung function in asymptomatic people with a history of respiratory disease
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effect of spinal manipulation on lung function in asymptomatic people with a history of respiratory disease

conditions.healthcondition: Lung function in individuals 'at risk' of developing chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD stage 0)

interventions.interventions: therapeutic massage to the posterior thoracic muscles for 15 minutes, spinal manipulation of the thoracic vertebral and costal joints for 5 minutes, standardised 6 minute walking treadmill exercise routine 3 x week for 3 weeks. All participants receive exercise; half of the participants receive massage and spinal manipulation before exercise
interventions.comparator: Exercise 3 x week for 3 weeks: 6 minute standardised treadmill walking

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary outcome 1: spirometry measurements of forced vital capacity (FVC) & forced expiratory volume in 1st second (FEV1)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Timepoints: pre and post intervention session i.e 3 x week over 3 weeks
Timepoints: pre and post intervention session i.e 3 x week over 3 weeks

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Total change in lung function via spirometry (initial and final FVC & FEV1)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: at initial and final interventions and 3 weeks post intervention i.e. 6 weeks after initial intervention

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: History of respiratory disease Below normal spirometry Ambulatory
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Current respiratory disease Non-ambulatory Contra-indicated to spinal manipulation

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Department of Health & Chiropractic Macquarie University Sydney New South Wales 2109

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The aim of this project is to investigate the relationship between the spine, rib cage and associated muscles and lung function following the administration of spinal manipulation and exercise. The project will be conducted on healthy people with a previous history of respiratory disease who have either normal or below normal current lung function.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Macquarie University Ethics Review Committee (Human Research)
ethicscommitee.ethicaddress: Macquarie University Sydney New South Wales 2109
